{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3657824,"name":"eli","username":"_monkey","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/_/d07c76/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-19T06:46:14.617Z","cooked":"

I’m using 2025 WPILib (2025.3.2) with updated 2023 robot code, from the start after installing WPILib 2025 I just couldn’t perform the build without the terminal responding with the “terminal process failed: path to shell executable “cmd.exe” does not exsist.”

I updated the code and nothing changed.
I uninstalled and reinstalled WPILib 2025, nothing changed.
I changed all the settings.json so it would have the path to cmd.exe properly set, nothing changed.
I forced the use of powershell, nothing changed.
I scowered the gradle commands for anything that seemed off, nothing seemed off.

The full terminal text is:

  • Executing task: gradlew build -Dorg.gradle.java.home=“C:\Users\Public\wpilib\2025\jdk”
  • The terminal process failed to launch: Path to shell executable “cmd.exe” does not exist.

I feel like I’ve done everything that could possibly solve this issue, but nothing is working. I’ve spent a few hours using AI trying to even get an idea of what’s going on, but to no avail. I’m new to software, so I also don’t know this too well, but all I know is that the build command is doing something it shouldn’t be, and I have no idea what to do or where to start.

Screenshot 2025-06-12 155936879×132 3.98 KB

Are you running in windows or mac/linux? How did you open VSCode?

I ask, because the wording of that error message feels linux-y to me (maybe WSL), where “cmd.exe” wouldn’t be a valid command.

See:

WPILIB build error - Path to shell executable "cmd.exe" does not exist Programming
So I have installed a fresh installation of WPILIB on my personal home computer, and started working on a standard template project, when I realized I could not build the code. I have installed the swerve-lib, PathPlannerLib, and CTRE-Phoenix vendor libraries. I did have another existing version of visual studio code installed before installing WPILIB. I tried setting the default profile shell to command line, tried installing the JDK again, reinstalled WPILIB, and running the gradle build from …

Make sure System32 is in your system’s PATH variable.

So… My team’s lead software guy came over to help and I realized that the path was supposed to be C:\Windows\System32, not C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe.
